articles.headline: Zuckerman Matches Murdoch’s Bid for Newsday
articles.snippet: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News, will make the argument that his bid is more attractive because it does not have the potential to fall into regulatory limbo.
articles.abstract: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News, will make the argument that his bid is more attractive because it does not have the potential to fall into regulatory limbo.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News, believes he can snatch Newsday from Rupert Murdoch without offering a dime more than the $580 million already on the table.

articles.headline: At Trade Show, China’s Police Shop for the West’s Latest
articles.snippet: In China, the world’s fastest-growing market for security and crime-control equipment, it is business as usual between Western multinationals and Chinese police agencies.
articles.abstract: In China, the world’s fastest-growing market for security and crime-control equipment, it is business as usual between Western multinationals and Chinese police agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  For the Chinese police agency boss who thought he had everything, the police equipment trade show here was a chance to scrutinize the latest offerings from manufacturers around the world for secretly copying computer hard drives, suppressing riots or collecting video surveillance of public streets.

articles.headline: Environmental Cost of Shipping Groceries Around the World
articles.snippet: Never has food moved around the world at the speed or in the amounts it has over the last few years. Now, many say it is time to make shippers and shoppers pay for the resulting pollution.
articles.abstract: Never has food moved around the world at the speed or in the amounts it has over the last few years. Now, many say it is time to make shippers and shoppers pay for the resulting pollution.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cod caught off Norway is shipped to China to be turned into filets, then shipped back to Norway for sale. Argentine lemons fill supermarket shelves on the Citrus Coast of Spain, as local lemons rot on the ground. Half of Europe’s peas are grown and packaged in Kenya.

articles.headline: Horatio Alger Multiplied by 1.3 Billion
articles.snippet: You hear constantly that China is a country of young people, but you really see it in business, where a whole generation of young entrepreneurs has gone from rags to riches.
articles.abstract: You hear constantly that China is a country of young people, but you really see it in business, where a whole generation of young entrepreneurs has gone from rags to riches.
articles.lead_paragraph: “My generation is very lucky,” said Feng Jun.

articles.headline: Big Fine Set for Wachovia to End Case
articles.snippet: The settlement ends a federal investigation into accusations that the bank allowed telemarketers to use its accounts to steal millions of dollars from unsuspecting victims.
articles.abstract: The settlement ends a federal investigation into accusations that the bank allowed telemarketers to use its accounts to steal millions of dollars from unsuspecting victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Wachovia Corporation agreed on Friday to pay as much as $144 million to end an investigation that accuses the bank of allowing telemarketers to use its accounts to steal millions of dollars.

articles.headline: Questions Linger on Scope of Iran’s Threat in Iraq
articles.snippet: Some U.S. officials said Iran seemed to have carefully calibrated its involvement, in contrast to other officials’ public portrayals of an intensified Iranian role.
articles.abstract: Some U.S. officials said Iran seemed to have carefully calibrated its involvement, in contrast to other officials’ public portrayals of an intensified Iranian role.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Mark Mazzetti, Steven Lee Myers and Thom Shanker.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Steven Lee Myers and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Sect Children Face Another World, but Still No TV
articles.snippet: Extraordinary steps are being taken to reduce the shock of foster care for children Texas seized from a polygamy sect.
articles.abstract: Extraordinary steps are being taken to reduce the shock of foster care for children Texas seized from a polygamy sect.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO  Workers at the Children’s Shelter on this city’s gritty west side began this week to remove anything and everything colored red from the walls, the floors, even from their clothes.
articles.byline: By Kirk Johnson and Dan Frosch

articles.headline: China Says It Is Ready to Meet Dalai Lama Envoys
articles.snippet: The breakthrough comes as officials have pivoted and moved to tamp down domestic anger over Tibet.
articles.abstract: The breakthrough comes as officials have pivoted and moved to tamp down domestic anger over Tibet.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  China appeared to bend to international pressure on Friday as the government announced it would meet with envoys of the Dalai Lama, an unexpected shift that comes as Tibetan unrest in western China has threatened to cast a pall over the Beijing Olympics in August.

articles.headline: Making Ships Green, in Port and at Sea
articles.snippet: The shipping industry has made little progress toward becoming greener, with the most resistance coming less from the shipping industry than from the big oil companies that supply the dirty fuel.
articles.abstract: The shipping industry has made little progress toward becoming greener, with the most resistance coming less from the shipping industry than from the big oil companies that supply the dirty fuel.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOTHENBURG, Sweden  Something unusual is happening in Swedish waters. Crews docking at the Port of Gothenburg are turning off their engines and plugging into the local power grid rather than burning diesel oil or sulfurous bunker fuel  a thick, black residue left over from refining oil.

articles.headline: Recession Diet Just One Way to Tighten Belt
articles.snippet: Americans are finding creative ways to cut costs on routine items, forcing retailers to decode the tastes of a suddenly thrifty public.
articles.abstract: Americans are finding creative ways to cut costs on routine items, forcing retailers to decode the tastes of a suddenly thrifty public.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stung by rising gasoline and food prices, Americans are finding creative ways to cut costs on routine items like groceries and clothing, forcing retailers, restaurants and manufacturers to decode the tastes of a suddenly thrifty public.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Eric Dash

articles.headline: BlackBerry’s Quest: Fend Off the iPhone
articles.snippet: Since the iPhone’s debut, the contours of the smartphone market have shifted rapidly toward consumers.
articles.abstract: Since the iPhone’s debut, the contours of the smartphone market have shifted rapidly toward consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: STEVE JOBS, Apple’s chief executive and field general, has Napoleonic dreams of global conquest for his 10-month-old wonder gadget, the iPhone. So it may be fitting that he’s encountering his most serious resistance in a city called Waterloo.

articles.headline: In Zimbabwe Jail: A Reporter’s Ordeal
articles.snippet: A Times reporter, jailed for “committing journalism” while reporting on the elections in Zimbabwe, writes about his ordeal.
articles.abstract: A Times reporter, jailed for “committing journalism” while reporting on the elections in Zimbabwe, writes about his ordeal.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — I had never been arrested before and the prospect of prison in Zimbabwe, one of the poorest, most repressive places on earth, seemed especially forbidding: the squalor, the teeming cells, the possibility of beatings. But I told myself what I’d repeatedly taught my two children: Life is a collection of experiences. You savor the good, you learn from the bad.

articles.headline: Wall Street, Run Amok
articles.snippet: How did all of the mechanisms operated by the mind-bogglingly well-paid men and women of the Street go so wrong?
articles.abstract: How did all of the mechanisms operated by the mind-bogglingly well-paid men and women of the Street go so wrong?
articles.lead_paragraph: You don’t really need to find out what’s going on.

articles.headline: 3 Candidates With 3 Financial Plans, but One Deficit
articles.snippet: The fiscal plans of both parties’ candidates could increase the national debt by trillions, experts say.
articles.abstract: The fiscal plans of both parties’ candidates could increase the national debt by trillions, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Republican and Democratic presidential candidates differ strikingly in their approaches to taxes and spending, but their fiscal plans have at least one thing in common: each could significantly swell the budget deficit and increase the national debt by trillions of dollars, according to tax and budget experts.
articles.byline: By Larry Rohter and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: Where Was the Wise Man?
articles.snippet: Robert E. Rubin mainly serves as Citigroup’s consigliere, but some still fault him for losses in the credit crisis.
articles.abstract: Robert E. Rubin mainly serves as Citigroup’s consigliere, but some still fault him for losses in the credit crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERY month or so, Citigroup invites a select group of clients to dine with a singular and very special host: Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary who, for the last nine years, has been the banking giant’s self-described consigliere.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Elite Korean Schools, Forging Ivy League Skills
articles.snippet: Two rigorous South Korean prep schools have achieved a spectacular record of admission to U.S. colleges.
articles.abstract: Two rigorous South Korean prep schools have achieved a spectacular record of admission to U.S. colleges.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea  It is 10:30 p.m. and students at the elite Daewon prep school here are cramming in a study hall that ends a 15-hour school day. A window is propped open so the evening chill can keep them awake. One teenager studies standing upright at his desk to keep from dozing.

articles.headline: Help for Those Seeking a Job and a Home
articles.snippet: Many of those attending an employment assistance program of the Praxis Housing Initiatives need to work on elementary job-seeking skills before they enter the work force.
articles.abstract: Many of those attending an employment assistance program of the Praxis Housing Initiatives need to work on elementary job-seeking skills before they enter the work force.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONE man is a former professional football player. The other has been a security guard and a short-order cook amid stints in prison for selling drugs. As different as their backgrounds are, both men are now homeless, jobless and infected with the virus that causes AIDS.

articles.headline: Loan Industry Fighting Rules on Mortgages
articles.snippet: One common industry criticism of the plan to put in place tougher regulations is that tighter rules could make many mortgages more expensive.
articles.abstract: One common industry criticism of the plan to put in place tougher regulations is that tighter rules could make many mortgages more expensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The mortgage industry, facing the prospect of tougher regulations for its central role in the housing crisis, has begun an intensive campaign to fight back.

articles.headline: Signs of Attacks on Zimbabwe’s Opposition
articles.snippet: There is growing evidence of widespread retribution against people who supported the opposition party.
articles.abstract: There is growing evidence of widespread retribution against people who supported the opposition party.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  Evidence of widespread retribution against people who supported Zimbabwe’s opposition party in last month’s election has begun to stream out despite the government’s efforts to restrict press access to the worst of the violence.

articles.headline: Dental Clinics, Meeting a Need With No Dentist
articles.snippet: A program in Alaska trains dental therapists to provide basic services in communities chronically underserved.
articles.abstract: A program in Alaska trains dental therapists to provide basic services in communities chronically underserved.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNALAKLEET, Alaska  The dental clinic in this village on the edge of the Bering Sea looks like any other, with four chairs, a well-scrubbed floor and a waiting area filled with magazines.

articles.headline: Murdoch’s ‘Head of Content’
articles.snippet: Robert Thomson, the new de-facto editor at The Wall Street Journal, is charged with executing the vision of its owner, Rupert Murdoch.
articles.abstract: Robert Thomson, the new de-facto editor at The Wall Street Journal, is charged with executing the vision of its owner, Rupert Murdoch.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a long career, Robert Thomson has left a trail of happy reporters in his wake  at The Financial Times and more recently at The Times of London, where the newsroom under his guidance was, in the words of a former colleague, “the happiest place to work on Fleet Street.”

articles.headline: Better Days, and Even the Candidates, Are Coming to W.W.E.
articles.snippet: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton, John McCain and Barack Obama appeared on World Wrestling Entertainment last week.
articles.abstract: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton, John McCain and Barack Obama appeared on World Wrestling Entertainment last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: For most of 2007, the reputation of World Wrestling Entertainment seemed to be in tatters, its ratings and share price staggering after a suicide-murder involving one of its biggest stars.

articles.headline: Revealing Photo Threatens a Major Disney Franchise
articles.snippet: A picture of Disney star Miley Cyrus posing in satin sheets in Vanity Fair has sparked outrage from parents.
articles.abstract: A picture of Disney star Miley Cyrus posing in satin sheets in Vanity Fair has sparked outrage from parents.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Fifteen years old and suggestively wrapped in what appears to be a satin bedsheet in the June issue of Vanity Fair. Did Miley Cyrus, with the help of a controversy-courting magazine, just deliver a blow to the Walt Disney Company’s billion-dollar “Hannah Montana” franchise?

articles.headline: At Journal, the Words Not Spoken
articles.snippet: Two departing high-ranking Wall Street Journal employees, including its managing editor, are under nondisparagement clauses.
articles.abstract: Two departing high-ranking Wall Street Journal employees, including its managing editor, are under nondisparagement clauses.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night, employees of The Wall Street Journal gathered in the Grill Room at the World Financial Center to bid farewell to Stuart Karle, the former general counsel of The Journal, a tenacious defender of journalism who is regarded as a reporter’s lawyer.

articles.headline: Continental Abandons Merger Talks With United
articles.snippet: Continental’s decision to remain an independent carrier was a blow to lengthy efforts by United to find a merger partner.
articles.abstract: Continental’s decision to remain an independent carrier was a blow to lengthy efforts by United to find a merger partner.
articles.lead_paragraph: Continental Airlines said Sunday that it had abandoned merger talks with United Airlines and was planning to remain an independent carrier, a blow to lengthy efforts by United to find a merger partner.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: Eyes on Blue-Collar Voters, Obama Shifts Style
articles.snippet: Working to appeal to working-class voters, the senator is trading big stadium rallies for town-hall-style meetings.
articles.abstract: Working to appeal to working-class voters, the senator is trading big stadium rallies for town-hall-style meetings.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANDERSON, Ind.  Senator Barack Obama is making subtle changes to his campaign style and message in an effort to strengthen his appeal to blue-collar voters and to avoid a defeat in Indiana that aides fear could give Democratic Party leaders further pause about his viability in a general election.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Reluctantly, a Daily Stops Its Presses, Living Online
articles.snippet: On Saturday, The Capital Times, the fabled 90-year-old daily newspaper of Madison, Wis., stopped printing to devote itself to publishing its daily report on the Web.
articles.abstract: On Saturday, The Capital Times, the fabled 90-year-old daily newspaper of Madison, Wis., stopped printing to devote itself to publishing its daily report on the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: With print revenue down and online revenue growing, newspaper executives are anticipating the day when big city dailies and national papers will abandon their print versions.

articles.headline: Election Day in Florida May Look Familiar
articles.snippet: Eight years after the “hanging chads,” experts say it is harder to vote in Florida than in nearly every other state.
articles.abstract: Eight years after the “hanging chads,” experts say it is harder to vote in Florida than in nearly every other state.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI  The League of Women Voters in Florida and its 27 local groups have helped thousands of residents register to vote over the years.
